lines.text:
[describing the running of the grunion]
During this time of the year the slippery little creatures come up on the beach, stop, spawn, then go out to sea again.
Sounds like some naval officers I know.
You know, she knows darn well that little piece of black lace is showin' up above her shirt.
You know what she is? A sadist. I know these black underwear kind of women.
Oddballs and freaks, that's what they are. The whole blasted public relations.
Get this ship under way and haul down those... those... bloomers!
You're taking good care of me, kid! Went to Harvard, didn't you, Junior?
Princeton.
Six of one, half a dozen of the other! They're both pantywaist factories. I never go within spittin' distance of a college myself.

[sotto voce]
I sensed that.
Correspondence Liaison Officer, any report on Admiral Boatwright?
Yes, sir. He refused to grant the 'Time' and 'Newsweek' interviews.
The admiral's one of those old-fashioned naval types who seems to believe that the Navy is merely a collection of ships.
Remarkable attitude.
Isn't it! What did he say, exactly?
Well, he said that the, uh, Public Relations outfit was a, uh, collection of oddballs and freaks.
Doesn't he realize our importance? The invaluable contribution that we're making?

Well, I'm afraid not, sir. As a matter of fact he suggested we load all the correspondents and public relations oddballs on one ship and steer that one ship right into the middle of Tokyo Bay. 'Cause he figures this would drive the enemy nuts and get the war over one year earlier.
Very funny.
Well, I thought it was kinda' funny, sir.
Good evening, lieutenant.
Hey, you look ravishing! What's that perfume?

[butting in]
Carbolic acid. She just scrubbed the operating room.

[chuckles]
Janie's incurably romantic.
